name: Itsukushima Shrine
short_description: UNESCO World Heritage shrine famous for its iconic 'floating' vermillion torii gate set in the Seto Inland Sea, one of Japan's most photographed landmarks.
description:
Itsukushima Shrine is one of Japan's most sacred Shinto shrines, located on the island of Miyajima in Hiroshima Bay. The shrine was first established in 593 AD and was later expanded by the powerful warlord Taira no Kiyomori in 1168 to its current grandeur. The complex is built on wooden piers extending over the sea, creating the illusion of floating during high tide.

The shrine's most famous feature is its massive vermillion torii gate standing 16 meters tall in the water, which has become one of Japan's most iconic images. The shrine buildings include the main hall (Honsha), worship hall, and several auxiliary shrines connected by covered corridors. At low tide, visitors can walk out to the torii gate.

Designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1996, Itsukushima Shrine attracts millions of visitors annually. The shrine is also home to important Shinto festivals, including the Kangen-sai boat procession featuring traditional court music. The nearby Mount Misen offers stunning views and hiking trails through primeval forests.

name: Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park
short_description: A powerful memorial complex dedicated to the victims of the atomic bombing, featuring the iconic A-Bomb Dome and Peace Memorial Museum.
description:
Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park is a profound memorial dedicated to the victims of the world's first nuclear attack on August 6, 1945. The park spans over 120,000 square meters in what was once the city's bustling commercial and political center before the bomb's detonation.

The park's most striking feature is the A-Bomb Dome (Genbaku Dome), the skeletal remains of the former Prefectural Industrial Promotion Hall that survived the blast. This UNESCO World Heritage Site serves as a powerful symbol of nuclear destruction and peace. The park also contains the Memorial Cenotaph, which holds the names of over 320,000 victims, and the eternal Peace Flame that will burn until all nuclear weapons are eliminated.

The Peace Memorial Museum provides extensive documentation of the bombing and its aftermath through artifacts, photographs, and survivor testimonies. The park hosts an annual peace ceremony on August 6th and serves as a global center for nuclear abolition advocacy.

name: Okayama Korakuen Garden
short_description: One of Japan's three most celebrated landscape gardens, featuring traditional elements, expansive lawns, tea houses, and views of Okayama Castle.
description:
Okayama Korakuen Garden is consistently ranked among Japan's three finest landscape gardens, alongside Kanazawa's Kenrokuen and Mito's Kairakuen. Built in 1700 under the orders of feudal lord Ikeda Tsunamasa, the garden was designed as a place of relaxation and entertainment for the ruling family.

The 13-hectare garden showcases classic elements of Japanese landscape design including central ponds, winding streams, walking paths, and borrowed scenery incorporating views of Okayama Castle across the Asahi River. Uniquely for a Japanese garden, Korakuen features spacious lawns, rice and tea fields, and a crane aviary where graceful birds are released on New Year's Day.

The garden changes dramatically with the seasons, from cherry blossoms in spring to autumn maples, making it a year-round destination. Special night illuminations are held during select periods. The garden received three stars in the Michelin Green Guide Japan and was designated a Special Place of Scenic Beauty in 1952.

name: Izumo Taisha Grand Shrine
short_description: One of Japan's oldest and most sacred Shinto shrines, dedicated to the deity of marriage and relationships, featuring the country's largest shimenawa rope.
description:
Izumo Taisha (Izumo Grand Shrine) is one of Japan's most ancient and venerated Shinto shrines, with origins predating recorded history. The shrine is dedicated to Okuninushi no Okami, the deity of good relationships, marriage, and nation-building according to Japanese mythology.

The current main hall (Honden), standing at 24 meters, is the tallest shrine building in Japan and is designated as a National Treasure. Built in the distinctive taisha-zukuri architectural style—the oldest form of shrine architecture in Japan—the hall was historically even taller, with records suggesting it once reached 48 meters. The shrine's massive shimenawa (sacred straw rope) at Kagura-den weighs an impressive 5.2 tons and measures 13.6 meters long.

The shrine holds special significance during the 10th lunar month (approximately November), when it's believed all Shinto deities from across Japan gather here for an annual meeting. Visitors clap four times instead of the usual two during prayers—twice for themselves and twice for their partners.

name: Tottori Sand Dunes
short_description: Japan's largest coastal sand dunes stretching 16km along the Sea of Japan, offering camel rides, sandboarding, and stunning natural landscapes.
description:
The Tottori Sand Dunes are Japan's largest coastal dune system, spanning approximately 16 kilometers along the Sea of Japan coast and reaching up to 2.4 kilometers inland. Part of the San'in Kaigan UNESCO Global Geopark, these dramatic landscapes were formed over 100,000 years from sediment carried by the Sendai River and shaped by powerful coastal winds.

The dunes reach heights of up to 50 meters and feature unique formations including bowl-shaped depressions called 'suribachi' and beautiful wind-ripple patterns. The area attracts over 1.3 million visitors annually who enjoy activities like camel riding, sandboarding, and paragliding. A chairlift takes visitors to observation decks for panoramic views of the golden sands meeting the blue sea.

The nearby Sand Museum is the world's only museum dedicated to sand sculptures, featuring elaborate works by international artists that change annually. The dunes offer different scenery throughout the day and seasons, with sunrise and sunset being particularly spectacular.

name: Kurashiki Bikan Historical Quarter
short_description: A beautifully preserved Edo-period merchant district featuring white-walled storehouses, willow-lined canals, and converted museums and cafes.
description:
The Kurashiki Bikan Historical Quarter is one of Japan's best-preserved merchant districts, retaining the atmosphere of the Edo period (1603-1868) when Kurashiki was an important rice distribution center under direct shogunate control. The area's iconic white-walled storehouses (kura) with distinctive namako walls gave the city its name.

The picturesque Kurashiki River flows through the heart of the quarter, lined with weeping willow trees and crossed by stone bridges. Visitors can take traditional boat rides along the canal for a unique perspective. Many former storehouses have been converted into museums, galleries, cafes, and shops selling local specialties like Kurashiki canvas bags and denim products from nearby Kojima.

The area is particularly renowned for the Ohara Museum of Art, Japan's first Western art museum, and Ivy Square, a former cotton mill transformed into a hotel and cultural complex. Evening illuminations transform the quarter into a romantic destination. The district has been designated as an Important Preservation District for Groups of Traditional Buildings.

name: Motonosumi Shrine
short_description: A stunning coastal shrine with 123 vermillion torii gates cascading down seaside cliffs, selected as one of CNN's '31 Most Beautiful Places in Japan'.
description:
Motonosumi Shrine is a visually spectacular Shinto shrine located on the rugged Sea of Japan coastline in northwestern Yamaguchi Prefecture. Established in 1955 after a local fisherman received a vision of a white fox spirit, the shrine gained international fame when CNN Travel named it one of Japan's 31 most beautiful places in 2015.

The shrine's most striking feature is its tunnel of 123 bright vermillion torii gates that wind down the clifftop toward the crashing waves below. The contrast of the red gates against the blue sea and green vegetation creates one of Japan's most photogenic scenes. Unique among Japanese shrines, the offering box is placed at the top of the final torii gate, 6 meters above ground—if your thrown coin lands in the box, your wish is said to come true.

Nearby is the Ryugu no Shiofuki ('Dragon Palace Spout'), a natural phenomenon where waves crash against coastal rocks to create spectacular water spouts. Though remote and best accessed by car, the shrine has become one of Yamaguchi Prefecture's most popular destinations.

name: Kintaikyo Bridge
short_description: One of Japan's three most famous bridges, a unique five-arched wooden structure spanning the Nishiki River, particularly beautiful during cherry blossom season.
description:
The Kintaikyo Bridge is one of Japan's most celebrated historical landmarks, a masterpiece of traditional wooden bridge engineering spanning the crystal-clear Nishiki River. First constructed in 1673 by the third feudal lord of Iwakuni, the bridge features five elegant wooden arches supported by massive stone pillars, a design that was revolutionary for its time.

The bridge stretches 193 meters in length and stands as a testament to Edo-period craftsmanship. After surviving for nearly 300 years, the original bridge was destroyed by a typhoon in 1950 but was faithfully reconstructed in 1953 using traditional techniques. The intricate joinery system uses no nails, with wooden pieces interlocking to support the structure.

The surrounding Kikko Park is particularly stunning during cherry blossom season in spring and maple season in autumn, when thousands of visitors gather for festivals and fireworks. A ropeway takes visitors up to Iwakuni Castle on the hilltop above, offering panoramic views of the bridge and river valley.

name: Matsue Castle
short_description: One of Japan's 12 original castles with a surviving keep, designated as a National Treasure and known as the 'Black Castle' for its dark exterior.
description:
Matsue Castle is one of only 12 original castles in Japan to retain its main keep in original wooden form, having survived earthquakes, fires, and the anti-feudal demolitions of the Meiji period. Completed in 1611 by feudal lord Horio Yoshiharu, the castle was designated as a National Treasure in 2015.

The imposing five-story keep (appearing as five stories from outside but containing six levels inside) stands 30 meters tall and is characterized by its dark black exterior, earning it the nickname 'Black Castle.' Built in the hulking style of war castles, it features defensive mechanisms including hidden rooms, arrow slits, and stone-dropping points. The interior houses a museum displaying samurai armor, weapons, and artifacts from the castle's 400-year history.

Surrounding the castle are beautiful moats where visitors can take traditional boat cruises (Horikawa Meguri) through narrow waterways lined with willow trees. The castle grounds offer stunning cherry blossom viewing in spring and are particularly atmospheric when illuminated during special nighttime openings.

name: Akiyoshido Cave
short_description: Japan's largest limestone cave, featuring spectacular underground formations, pools, and a constant 17°C temperature year-round.
description:
Akiyoshido Cave is Japan's largest and second-longest limestone cave, stretching over 10.7 kilometers beneath the Akiyoshidai plateau, with approximately 1 kilometer open to the public. Designated as a Special Natural Monument, the cave formed over hundreds of millions of years and offers a glimpse into the region's ancient geological history when it was a coral reef beneath the sea.

The cave features stunning natural formations including massive stalagmites, stalactites, and the famous 'Hyakumaizara' (Hundred Plates)—a series of rimstone pools resembling terraced rice paddies filled with clear water. The entrance itself is impressive at 24 meters high and 8 meters wide, with an underground river flowing out. Inside, the cave maintains a constant temperature of 17°C year-round, making it cool in summer and warm in winter.

Visitors walk along well-lit, paved pathways past named formations like the 'Golden Pillar' and 'Umbrella Forest.' An elevator connects the cave to the Akiyoshidai Karst Observatory above, allowing visitors to explore both the underground wonders and the spectacular above-ground karst landscape.

name: Mount Daisen
short_description: The highest peak in the Chugoku region at 1,729m, nicknamed 'Hoki Fuji' for its resemblance to Mt. Fuji, offering excellent hiking and skiing.
description:
Mount Daisen is a majestic dormant volcano and the highest mountain in the Chugoku region, standing at 1,729 meters. Part of the Daisen-Oki National Park, the mountain has been a center of mountain worship for over 1,300 years and is included in Japan's list of 100 Famous Mountains.

The mountain's profile when viewed from the south resembles Mount Fuji, earning it the nickname 'Hoki Fuji.' However, from different angles, the mountain reveals dramatically different faces, including rugged cliff walls formed by Japan's largest lava dome. The slopes are covered with Western Japan's most extensive beech forest, which turns brilliant gold and red in autumn.

The popular Natsuyama hiking course from Daisenji Temple takes approximately 3 hours to reach Misen Peak (1,709m), passing through ancient beech forests before emerging onto scenic wooden boardwalks near the summit with panoramic views of the Sea of Japan. In winter, several ski resorts offer quality slopes with ocean views. The historic Daisenji Temple at the mountain's base features sacred buildings and moss-covered stone paths.

name: Ohara Museum of Art
short_description: Japan's first Western art museum, housing masterpieces by El Greco, Monet, Renoir, and Gauguin in a stunning Greco-Roman style building.
description:
The Ohara Museum of Art is Japan's first private museum dedicated to Western art, established in 1930 by local industrialist Ohara Magosaburo to commemorate his friend, the painter Kojima Torajiro, who had died the previous year. The museum's neo-classical main building with its impressive Ionic columns creates a striking contrast to the traditional storehouses of the surrounding Bikan Historical Quarter.

The collection began with works Kojima selected during three trips to Europe funded by Ohara, and now includes over 3,000 pieces spanning from the Italian Renaissance to contemporary art. Highlights include El Greco's 'Annunciation,' Monet's 'Water Lilies,' and works by Renoir, Gauguin, Picasso, and Kandinsky. The collection has expanded to include modern Japanese painting, folk art from the Mingei movement, and Asian antiquities.

The museum complex includes the Main Gallery, Craft Art & Asian Gallery housed in converted Edo-period rice warehouses, and beautiful gardens featuring works by Henry Moore and Isamu Noguchi. The adjacent Cafe El Greco, built in 1959, offers a charming spot to reflect on the artwork.

name: Hiroshima Castle
short_description: A faithful reconstruction of the original 1590s castle, nicknamed 'Carp Castle,' now housing a museum of Hiroshima's pre-war history.
description:
Hiroshima Castle, also known as 'Carp Castle' (Rijō) for its resemblance to the fish, was originally built in the 1590s by the powerful feudal lord Mōri Terumoto. The five-story castle served as the center of western Japan's power until the Meiji period, when it became an important military base.

The original castle was destroyed in the atomic bombing of August 6, 1945, with only stone foundations surviving. The current structure is a faithful exterior reconstruction completed in 1958 using reinforced concrete, standing as a symbol of Hiroshima's remarkable post-war recovery. The castle's white and gray walls are surrounded by a wide moat that reflects the tower beautifully.

The interior houses a comprehensive museum documenting Hiroshima's history before the war, castle culture in Japan, and the history of Japanese fortifications. Exhibits include samurai armor, swords, and detailed models showing the castle's original layout. The top floor observation deck offers panoramic views of the Peace Memorial Park, the city, and surrounding mountains. The castle grounds feature beautiful cherry trees that bloom spectacularly each spring.

name: Adachi Museum of Art
short_description: A museum renowned for its Japanese garden rated #1 in Japan for over 20 consecutive years, combined with an excellent collection of modern Japanese art.
description:
The Adachi Museum of Art is a remarkable fusion of Japanese garden design and modern art, founded in 1970 by local businessman Adachi Zenko. The museum's Japanese garden has been rated the best in Japan by the Journal of Japanese Gardening for over 20 consecutive years, surpassing even Katsura Imperial Villa in Kyoto.

The 165,000 square meter grounds feature multiple garden types seamlessly integrated into the surrounding landscape, including a Dry Landscape Garden, White Gravel and Pine Garden, Moss Garden, and Pond Garden. The museum building is designed so that each window frames the garden as a living painting, with distant Mount Daisen incorporated as 'borrowed scenery.' Maintenance crews work daily to keep every element immaculate.

The art collection focuses on modern Japanese painting, with over 1,500 works including the largest collection of Yokoyama Taikan paintings in existence. Other featured artists include Uemura Shōen, Kawai Gyokudō, and contemporary ceramicists. The museum philosophy treats the garden itself as the ultimate work of art, demonstrating that nature and art are fundamentally connected.

name: Onomichi
short_description: A charming hillside port town with narrow temple-lined paths, scenic views, and the gateway to the Shimanami Kaido cycling route.
description:
Onomichi is a historic port town built on steep hillsides along the Seto Inland Sea, famous for its maze of narrow lanes, stone steps, and 25 temples that have inspired countless Japanese poets, writers, and filmmakers. The town's literary associations earned it the nickname 'The Town of Literature.'

The hillside Temple Walk (Koji) leads visitors past ancient shrines and temples connected by stone paths offering stunning views over the harbor dotted with islands. Notable temples include Senkoji Temple, accessible by ropeway, which offers panoramic views from its mountaintop observation deck. The town's nostalgic atmosphere, with traditional wooden buildings, old movie theaters, and winding alleyways, has made it a popular setting for Japanese films.

Onomic serves as the starting point for the famous Shimanami Kaido, a 70-kilometer cycling route crossing six islands to Shikoku via a series of bridges. The route is considered one of the world's most beautiful cycling courses. The town is also known for its unique ramen, featuring a pork and seafood broth with flat noodles.

name: Hagi
short_description: A well-preserved castle town that produced many leaders of Japan's Meiji Restoration, famous for its historic samurai district and Hagi pottery.
description:
Hagi is an atmospheric former castle town that played a pivotal role in Japanese history as the birthplace of many leaders of the Meiji Restoration who modernized Japan in the late 19th century. The town's well-preserved samurai district, pottery tradition, and historic sites earned several UNESCO World Heritage designations as part of the 'Sites of Japan's Meiji Industrial Revolution.'

The old samurai and merchant quarters retain their Edo-period layout with white-walled buildings, earthen walls topped with distinctive tiles, and narrow lanes lined with summer orange trees. The Shoin Shrine commemorates Yoshida Shoin, an influential educator whose students became key figures in modernizing Japan. His former school, Shoka Sonjuku Academy, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Hagi is equally famous for Hagiyaki pottery, a rustic style prized in the tea ceremony. The town has numerous pottery studios where visitors can watch masters work or try their hand at the craft. The ruins of Hagi Castle sit on a peninsula, and the surrounding area is known for beautiful cherry blossoms in spring.

name: Tsuwano
short_description: A picturesque mountain valley town known as 'Little Kyoto of San'in,' featuring carp-filled canals, historic temples, and traditional streetscapes.
description:
Tsuwano is a remarkably preserved former castle town nestled in a scenic mountain valley, often called the 'Little Kyoto of San'in' for its refined traditional atmosphere. Despite its remote location, the town was an important center of culture and learning during the Edo period.

The main street, Tono-machi, is lined with white-walled samurai residences and merchant houses, with stone-lined channels running alongside the streets filled with hundreds of brilliantly colored koi carp—a unique feature that has become Tsuwano's symbol. The Catholic church, a rare sight in rural Japan, commemorates the martyrdom of Christians who were exiled here during persecution in the late 1800s.

Above the town, the Taikodani Inari Shrine features a tunnel of nearly 1,000 vermillion torii gates climbing the mountainside—one of Japan's five largest Inari shrines. The ruins of Tsuwano Castle can be reached by chairlift and offer commanding views of the valley below. The town is also known for its traditional papermaking and sake brewing.

name: Shimanami Kaido
short_description: A stunning 70km cycling and driving route connecting Honshu to Shikoku across six islands via spectacular bridges over the Seto Inland Sea.
description:
The Shimanami Kaido is a 70-kilometer expressway connecting Onomichi in Hiroshima Prefecture to Imabari in Ehime Prefecture across six islands in the Seto Inland Sea. Unlike other bridge routes, the Shimanami Kaido features dedicated cycling and walking paths, making it one of the world's most scenic cycling routes.

The route crosses six islands—Mukaishima, Innoshima, Ikuchijima, Omishima, Hakatajima, and Oshima—via a series of spectacular suspension bridges. Each island offers unique attractions: citrus orchards, ancient temples, beaches, and local seafood. The Tatara Bridge, spanning 1,480 meters, is one of the world's longest cable-stayed bridges and offers stunning views.

Bicycle rental stations are conveniently located along the route with drop-off points allowing one-way journeys. The cycling infrastructure includes clearly marked paths, rest stations, and gentle inclines onto bridges. While experienced cyclists complete the route in 4-5 hours, most visitors take a full day to enjoy the scenery, local food, and attractions. The route is equally beautiful by car or motorcycle.

name: Tomonoura
short_description: A picturesque historic port town that inspired Studio Ghibli's Ponyo, featuring Edo-period architecture and beautiful harbor views.
description:
Tomonoura is a remarkably preserved historic port town located at the midpoint of the Seto Inland Sea, where it flourished as a crucial stop for ships waiting for favorable tides. The town retains much of its Edo-period character, with narrow streets, traditional wooden buildings, and distinctive harbor facilities that served the maritime trade for centuries.

The town gained international recognition as the primary inspiration for Hayao Miyazaki's acclaimed animated film 'Ponyo.' The director spent extended time here, and visitors can recognize many locations from the film. The iconic Joyato lighthouse, a stone-and-wood structure built in 1859, stands at the harbor entrance and is one of Japan's oldest surviving lighthouses.

Historic landmarks include the Fukuzenji Temple, where a Korean diplomatic mission stayed in 1711 and declared the view of the harbor the most beautiful in Japan. Taishiden Temple houses important Buddhist artifacts, while the Iroha-maru Museum tells the story of a steamship sunk here involving the famous samurai Sakamoto Ryoma. The quiet atmosphere and unchanged streetscapes make Tomonoura feel like stepping back in time.

name: Rurikoji Temple
short_description: Home to one of Japan's three most beautiful five-story pagodas, a National Treasure built in 1442 in elegant Muromachi-period style.
description:
Rurikoji Temple is a Zen Buddhist temple renowned for its exquisite five-story pagoda, which is considered one of Japan's three most beautiful pagodas alongside those at Horyuji in Nara and Daigoji in Kyoto. The pagoda was designated as a National Treasure and represents the pinnacle of Muromachi-period architecture.

Built in 1442 by the Ouchi clan to pray for the soul of their lord Ouchi Moriharu, the 31.2-meter pagoda exhibits refined proportions and elegant details that exemplify the aesthetic sensibilities of medieval Japan. The structure has survived for nearly 600 years, standing gracefully against a backdrop of forested hills in the historic Kozan Park area, which was designed to resemble Kyoto.

The temple grounds are particularly beautiful in spring when cherry blossoms frame the pagoda, and in autumn when maple leaves create a spectacular contrast. The nearby Toshunji Temple contains the graves of the Mori clan lords who ruled the region during the Edo period. After sunset, the pagoda is illuminated, creating a magical nighttime scene that draws photographers and visitors alike.

name: Okayama Castle
short_description: A striking black castle nicknamed 'Crow Castle' standing across the river from Korakuen Garden, offering hands-on samurai experiences.
description:
Okayama Castle, nicknamed 'Crow Castle' (Ujo) for its distinctive black exterior, was originally built in 1597 by feudal lord Ukita Hideie. The castle's dark wooden panels contrast dramatically with the more common white castles of Japan, making it one of the country's most visually striking fortresses.

The original castle was destroyed during World War II air raids, and the current structure is a 1966 concrete reconstruction that faithfully replicates the exterior. The castle features a unique asymmetrical layout, with the main tower offset from the center—a design that was considered innovative for its time.

Inside, the castle houses a museum with exhibitions on local history and the castle's construction. Visitors can try on samurai armor and kimono for photos, and the top floor observation deck offers views of Korakuen Garden across the Asahi River. The castle and garden are connected by a bridge, and a combined ticket allows visits to both attractions. The castle is illuminated at night, creating beautiful reflections on the river, and special events include rooftop beer gardens in summer.

name: Daisenji Temple
short_description: An ancient Buddhist temple at the base of Mt. Daisen with over 1,300 years of history, featuring moss-covered stone paths and sacred halls.
description:
Daisenji Temple is a sacred Buddhist temple with a history spanning over 1,300 years, located at the base of Mount Daisen—the spiritual heart of mountain worship in the San'in region. Founded in 718, the temple once rivaled Mount Koya and Mount Hiei as a major center of religious practice, with over 100 temples and 3,000 warrior monks at its peak.

The temple's main approach is a atmospheric stone-paved path lined with ancient cedar trees, their roots covered in velvety moss. The path leads through sacred spaces that have inspired pilgrims and poets for centuries. The main hall (Amida-do) from the Muromachi period is designated an Important Cultural Property and houses significant Buddhist statues.

Above the temple, reached by a continuation of the stone path, is Ogamiyama Shrine—one of Japan's finest examples of gongen-style shrine architecture, featuring stunning painted interiors. The temple serves as the traditional starting point for climbers ascending Mount Daisen via the Natsuyama hiking trail. In autumn, the surrounding beech forests transform into brilliant fall colors, while winter brings a mystical snow-covered landscape.
